name: Hveragerði
description: Hveragerði is a geothermally active town of approximately 2,700 residents located 45 kilometers east of Reykjavík in South Iceland, often called "The Hot Springs Capital of the World" and "Earthquake Town" due to its remarkable geological characteristics. Situated within the highly active geothermal field of the Hengill central volcano system, the town experiences very frequent seismic activity—usually minor tremors that residents have learned to live with, though occasionally more significant earthquakes occur. On May 29, 2008, a powerful magnitude 6.3 earthquake struck with its epicenter just 2 kilometers southeast of Hveragerði, causing substantial damage to buildings and infrastructure while fortunately resulting in no fatalities. The town's very existence and development are intimately tied to geothermal activity, with hot springs, steam vents, and bubbling mud pools dotting the landscape throughout the settlement and surrounding hillsides. This abundant natural heat revolutionized Icelandic horticulture when the first geothermally-heated greenhouse was established in Hveragerði in 1923, enabling year-round cultivation of vegetables and flowers despite Iceland's harsh Arctic winters. This innovation positioned Hveragerði as Iceland's horticultural capital, and today the town produces tomatoes, cucumbers, bell peppers, tropical fruits, and famously bananas in heated greenhouses, making it the world's northernmost banana-producing location. Visitors can tour operational greenhouses to witness tropical plants thriving in a sub-Arctic environment.
